pageDescription: Discover the three reference projects building the infrastructure for regenerative governance: Communize, CivicBase, and Stuga.

hero.title: From Theory to Practice
hero.subtitle: Building the Infrastructure for a Regenerative World
hero.description: Global Governance Frameworks isn't just theoretical blueprints—we're actively building the open-source infrastructure required to actualize them. These three projects represent the social, technical, and applied layers enabling local resilience and global cooperation.

layers.title: The Three Layers of Transformation
layers.intro: Together, these projects form a complete ecosystem for resilient, sovereign community development.

social.title: The Social Protocol
social.description: Communize provides the social patterns, practices, and wisdom needed to build trust-based communities and manage shared resources.

technical.title: The Technical Foundation
technical.description: CivicBase provides the P2P database infrastructure ensuring your community's data belongs to your community, not a cloud company—and works even when the internet is down.

application.title: The Lived Application
application.description: Stuga translates social protocols and technical capacity into concrete tools for neighborhood resilience and mutual support.

communize.title: Communize
communize.intro: A philosophical and practical exploration of building community and creating the commons. As a statically-hosted, open-source sister site to spiralize.org and nondualize.org, it extends the exploration of human development and consciousness into the social and structural realm.

inquiry.title: Our Inquiry
inquiry.description: Communize is built on the premise that the future of human flourishing is collective. We investigate:
inquiry.point1: The Process of Communizing: What does it mean to 'make communal'? How do we transform isolated ownership into shared stewardship?
inquiry.point2: The Psychology of Belonging: What are the human needs for connection, and how do healthy communities fulfill them?
inquiry.point3: The Structures of Collaboration: From ancient commons to digital cooperatives, we study models that enable people to manage shared resources.
inquiry.point4: Communizing as an Antidote: How does building community address modern crises of loneliness, ecological degradation, and economic inequality?

philosophical.title: Philosophical & Psychological Foundations
philosophical.description: Foundational texts on the theory of the commons, gift economies, and communalism. Connections between Spiral Dynamics, Nondualism, and community building.

models.title: Models & Praxis Library
models.description: Case studies of successful ecovillages, housing co-ops, and worker-owned businesses. Practical guides for starting tool libraries, forming babysitting cooperatives, or establishing community gardens.

toolkit.title: The Communize Toolkit
toolkit.description: Static resource mapper, curated tool directory for decision-making and participatory budgeting, and DIY worksheet generator for community asset mapping.

knowledge.title: The Knowledge Commons
knowledge.description: Thematically organized reading lists, link library to external organizations, projects, and research papers.

approach.title: Technical Approach
approach.description: Built with 11ty (Eleventy) or plain HTML + Markdown for ultimate simplicity and speed. Hosted on GitHub Pages—free, simple, and perfectly suited for this content-based project. All content written in Markdown, easy for anyone to contribute to.

civicbase.title: CivicBase
civicbase.intro: Offline-first infrastructure for Swedish municipal resilience. P2P database system ensuring critical services continue functioning even when cables are cut or the internet fails.

problem.title: The Problem
problem.incident: November 2024: Undersea cables in the Baltic Sea were severed between Sweden-Lithuania and Finland-Germany. Swedish municipalities, 95% dependent on American cloud infrastructure (AWS, Azure, Google Cloud), would have completely failed during extended outages.
problem.point1: Payment systems (Swish, BankID) require central servers + continuous internet
problem.point2: Municipal IT runs entirely in foreign clouds
problem.point3: No offline capability for critical services
problem.conclusion: When cables are cut, Swedish society stops.

solution.title: The Solution
solution.description: CivicBase is peer-to-peer infrastructure that enables Swedish municipalities to maintain critical services during infrastructure disruptions. Built on libp2p (proven technology powering IPFS/Filecoin globally):

offline.title: Offline-first operation
offline.description: Services continue via mesh networks when internet fails

sovereignty.title: Data sovereignty
sovereignty.description: All data stays in Sweden on Swedish devices

privacy.title: Privacy by Physics, Not Policy
privacy.description: Agent-centric design where each citizen controls their data on their device. End-to-end encryption makes data mathematically sealed. No central database to hack, leak, or subpoena.

sovereign.title: Sovereign Connectivity
sovereign.description: Peer-to-peer networking (libp2p) and mesh networks maintain local coordination when internet fails. Eliminates dependency on foreign cloud providers.

resilience.title: Resilience Over Efficiency
resilience.description: Graceful degradation, never total failure. Offline capability is default, not exception. 72-hour resilience target for critical functions.

dualUse.title: Dual-Use Infrastructure
dualUse.description: Peacetime: Municipal innovation (TAK-405, DPOP, DiDiS). Crisis: Critical redundancy (economic continuity, resource coordination).

applications.title: Applications
applications.intro: CivicBase is a platform, not a single application. It enables:

tak405.title: TAK-405 'The Region's Nervous System'
tak405.description: Transit wellness system for Stockholm public transport. Uses Hearts currency to incentivize helping behavior, reducing psychological stress. Proof-of-concept for offline economic transactions.

dpop.title: DPOP (Democratic Party Operations Platform)
dpop.description: Political organizing that continues during cable cuts. Meetings, decisions, coordination—all offline-capable with sync when connectivity returns.

didis.title: DiDiS (Distributed Digital Identity System)
didis.description: Privacy-preserving identity verification without central databases. Agent-centric architecture means no single point of compromise.

applications.future: Future: Healthcare records, elder care coordination, emergency response, climate adaptation—any municipal service requiring crisis resilience.

stuga.title: Stuga
stuga.intro: Local-first digital infrastructure for neighborhood resilience. Coordinate resources, crisis response, and mutual support—even when the internet is down.

purpose.title: Purpose and Vision
purpose.description: Stuga translates CivicBase's technical capacity and Communize's social protocols into concrete tools for neighborhood resilience. It's the lived application where theory becomes action—where P2P databases and trust-based communities meet people's daily needs.

coordination.title: Neighborhood Coordination
coordination.description: Map local resources, skills, and needs. Build networks of mutual support that can be activated during both ordinary times and crisis.

resources.title: Resource Sharing
resources.description: From tool libraries to food co-ops, Stuga facilitates sharing of common resources with offline-first functionality.

crisis.title: Crisis Response
crisis.description: When emergencies arise, Stuga enables rapid coordination of local response even when centralized communication systems have failed.

mutual.title: Mutual Support
mutual.description: Integration with Hearts currency from TAK-405 to enable local economic transactions and recognition of contributions to the community.

integration.title: Integration with the Ecosystem
integration.description: Stuga runs on CivicBase infrastructure for offline-first data handling and uses social protocols from Communize for community building. It's the practical manifestation of both projects—the proof that resilient, sovereign local organization is possible.

integration.title: How They Work Together
integration.intro: These three projects form a coherent ecosystem for local resilience:

step1.title: Communize Provides the Social Patterns
step1.description: Teaching how to build trust, manage commons, and create decision-making systems that respect both individual autonomy and collective wisdom.

step2.title: CivicBase Provides the Technical Foundation
step2.description: Offering offline-first P2P database, encryption, and mesh networking that ensures local data stays local and services work even when centralized infrastructure fails.

step3.title: Stuga Provides the Lived Application
step3.description: Translating social protocols and technical capacity into concrete tools for neighborhood coordination, resource sharing, and crisis response.

integration.summary: Together, they demonstrate that regenerative governance isn't just possible in theory—it's being actively built, codebase by codebase, community by community.

finalCta.title: Build the Future with Us
finalCta.description: These projects are open source and actively developed. Whether you're a developer, community organizer, or decision-maker—there's a way for you to contribute to building resilient infrastructure for a regenerative world.
